metadata.titleEn: HiWATER：Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (eddy covariance system of Shenshawo desert station, 2014)
metadata.description:
The data set contains the vortex correlativity data of shenshawo desert station in the middle reaches of heihe hydrometeorological observation network from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014.The site is located in zhangye city, gansu province.The latitude and longitude of the observation point are 100.49330E, 38.78917N, and 1594.00m above sea level.The height of the vortex correlation instrument is 4.6m, the sampling frequency is 10Hz, the ultrasonic direction is due to the north, and the distance between the ultrasonic wind speed and temperature instrument (CSAT3) and the CO2/H2O analyzer (Li7500) is 15cm.
The original observation data of vorticity correlativity is 10Hz, and the released data is the data of 30 minutes processed by Eddypro software. The main steps of its processing include: outfield value elimination, delay time correction, coordinate rotation (secondary coordinate rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction and density (WPL) correction.Quality assessment for each intercompared to at the same time, mainly is the atmospheric stability (Δ st) and turbulent characteristics of similarity (ITC) test.The 30min pass value output by Eddypro software was also screened.(2) data of 1h before and after precipitation were excluded;(3) the missing rate of 10Hz original data is more than 10% every 30min;(4) the observed data of weak turbulence at night were excluded (u* less than 0.1m/s).The average period of observation data was 30 minutes, 48 data a day, and the missing data was marked as -6999.Suspicious data caused by instrument drift shall be identified in red.
Observations published include:Date/Time for the Date/Time, wind Wdir (°), Wnd horizontal wind speed (m/s), standard deviation Std_Uy lateral wind speed (m/s), ultrasonic virtual temperature Tv (℃), the water vapor density H2O (g/m3), carbon dioxide concentration CO2 (mg/m3), friction velocity Ustar) (m/s), stability Z/L (dimensionless), sensible heat flux Hs (W/m2), latent heat flux LE (W/m2), carbon dioxide flux Fc (mg/(m2s)), the quality of the sensible heat flux identifier QA_Hs, the quality of the latent heat flux identifier QA_LE,Carbon dioxide flux mass identification QA_Fc.The quality of the sensible heat and latent heat, carbon dioxide flux identification is divided into three (quality id 0: (Δ st < 30, the ITC < 30);1: (Δ st < 100, ITC < 100);The rest are 2).The meaning of data time, such as 0:30 represents the average between 0:00 and 0:30;The data is stored in *.xls format.
Please refer to Li et al.(2013) for hydrometeorological network or site information, and Liu et al.(2011) for observation data processing.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems, particularly regarding eco-hydrological processes?
Definition.Answer: Data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems faces challenges primarily due to the poor availability of multiscale observations necessary for understanding eco-hydrological processes. These ecosystems are characterized by their heterogeneous surfaces, making it difficult to capture comprehensive data across different scales. Additionally, the arid conditions and complex interactions between oasis and desert systems require sophisticated instrumentation and observational strategies to ensure accurate data collection.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the Black River Ecological Hydrological Remote Sensing Experiment compare to those employed in Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in terms of capturing multiscale ecological processes?
Comparison.Answer: The Black River Ecological Hydrological Remote Sensing Experiment focuses on hydrometeorological observations using eddy covariance systems and specific data processing methods like Eddypro software. In contrast, HiWATER employs a multiscale approach with hierarchically nested instrumentation, including eddy covariance towers, scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing missions using LiDAR and other advanced imaging technologies to capture multiscale and multidisciplinary eco-hydrological processes.

Interpretation.Question: How do the data collection techniques employed in oasis-desert systems help address the challenges of eco-hydrological process upscaling?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection techniques in oasis-desert systems, such as the use of hierarchically nested scales and a combination of ground-based observations with airborne remote sensing, help address the challenges of upscaling eco-hydrological processes by capturing multi-scale interactions and providing comprehensive datasets. This approach facilitates a better understanding of the complex interactions in these systems, contributing to improved modeling and prediction capabilities.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy and the uncertainty in surface-air temperature difference. Errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature can also impact the estimates. Additionally, the strong advective environment contributes to these challenges.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the availability of multiscale observations a critical issue in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The availability of multiscale observations is crucial because it allows for the capture of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. The lack of such data hinders progress in this field, as multi-scale and multidisciplinary data are necessary to understand and model the complex interactions in heterogeneous surfaces effectively.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the errors in the estimation of soil and canopy component temperatures using thermal cameras?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in the estimation of soil and canopy component temperatures using thermal cameras are primarily caused by image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. Such errors can lead to overestimation of the canopy temperature. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance can produce uncertainties in the estimated temperatures, further contributing to errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the possible outcomes of implementing a hierarchical instrumentation approach on the quality and depth of multiscale eco-hydrological data collection?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing a hierarchical instrumentation approach, such as that used in the HiWATER experiment, can significantly enhance the quality and depth of multiscale eco-hydrological data collection. This approach allows for capturing multi-scale processes by arranging instruments in hierarchically nested scales, providing comprehensive data across different landscapes, such as oasis and desert interactions, and supporting extensive field and remote-sensing observations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts of long-term observational datasets on understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observational datasets can provide critical insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems. These datasets, comprising measurements from eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations, allow for a quantitative understanding of these exchanges, supporting ecological stability and sustainable development. They also help recognize the interactions between oasis and desert systems, which is essential for achieving carbon neutrality and protecting ecological security.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of implementing multi-scale and multidisciplinary data collection techniques in an oasis-desert system?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface by obtaining multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to achieve this through the use of instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, which captures multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and facilitates a better understanding of oasis-desert interactions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intentions behind creating a dataset of long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis-desert areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to develop a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems to support ecological stability and socioeconomic development. This knowledge aids in achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals while ensuring sustainable oasis development through the protection of ecological balance between oasis and desert systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instruments and procedures are used to collect and preprocess hydrometeorological data in oasis-desert systems before analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Instruments such as eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations are used. Data collection involves measuring turbulent fluxes, radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature, humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. The preprocessing includes calibration, data collection, data processing, and quality control throughout these steps.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are ground-based observations integrated with remote sensing techniques to estimate evapotranspiration over heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Ground-based measurements such as those from meteorological parameters and eddy covariance systems are combined with remote sensing techniques like LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers. These are used to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, and the field observations are applied to partition evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration using models like the Craig–Gordon model.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific challenges are faced in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, and how are they addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include the incomplete energy balance closure in eddy covariance flux measurements and uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences due to errors in determining component temperatures. These are addressed by using high-resolution thermal cameras to obtain soil and canopy component temperatures, which are used as inputs to models like the TSEB model to improve accuracy in estimating surface fluxes.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do advancements in remote sensing technologies improve the data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in remote sensing technologies, including the use of LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers, improve data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert systems by providing hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing data that complement ground-based observations.

Expectation.Question: Why might the current temperature separation approaches in arid regions be limited in effectiveness when using composite radiometric temperatures?
Expectation.Answer: The effectiveness of current composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions is limited due to errors primarily caused by image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. These errors can lead to overestimation of canopy temperature, especially in areas with developing vegetation abundance. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance may introduce uncertainties in estimated temperatures.

Expectation.Question: Why is it challenging to accurately estimate surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas using models?
Expectation.Answer: Estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging because the EC flux measurements of sensible and latent heat have incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy. Uncertainty in surface-air temperature difference, errors in determining component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures, and the strong advective environment contribute to this difficulty.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in arid regions, especially for long-term data collection efforts?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial for sustainable oasis development and achieving goals like carbon neutrality. Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems is important for ecological security and socioeconomic development. Long-term observations are indispensable in recognizing oasis-desert interactions and protecting ecological stability.

Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection techniques in oasis-desert systems, such as the use of hierarchically nested scales and a combination of ground-based and airborne remote sensing instruments, aim to address the challenges of multiscale observations. Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of using eddy covariance systems for measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential limitations of using eddy covariance systems in heterogeneous landscapes include the possibility of incomplete energy balance closure, particularly in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas. The uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences and errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures can affect the accuracy of flux measurements. Additionally, image classification errors in the derived component temperatures due to varying vegetation abundance can lead to overestimations or inaccuracies in the data.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can existing datasets on oasis-desert areas be expanded or refined to better support ecological security and sustainable development goals?
Judgmental.Answer: Existing datasets on oasis-desert areas can be expanded or refined by incorporating long-term observations that include energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. Enhancing the quality control procedures throughout sensor calibration, data collection, and data processing can improve the reliability of these datasets. Additionally, integrating ground-based measurements with high-resolution remote sensing data can provide more comprehensive insights into the interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems, thereby supporting ecological security and sustainable development goals.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the eddy covariance system measurements are processed to ensure accuracy and reliability in the context of this environmental study.
Assertion.Answer: The eddy covariance measurements undergo rigorous processing steps including outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation (double rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction to ensure accuracy. Quality evaluation is performed based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics, and data are filtered to exclude periods with instrument errors or insufficient turbulence.

Assertion.Answer: Challenges in separating soil and canopy component temperatures arise from image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. Errors in component temperature can result from soil pixels being classified as vegetation pixels, leading to overestimation of canopy temperatures. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance can introduce uncertainties in temperature estimations.
